docs.lead_paragraph: Readers of the Prescriptions blog reacted with bafflement, hope and consternation on Monday as the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, announced his intention to push for a government-run health insurance plan that states could decline to participate in. A sampling of readers' comments:
docs.abstract: Readers' comments from Prescriptions blog in response to Sen Harry Reid's intention to push for government-run health insurance plan that states could decline to participate in (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has designated Nov. 5 a nationwide ''Day of Action'' for its eight million union members to press their representatives in Congress to support sweeping health care legislation, including a government-run insurance option. ''We hope to flood the halls of Congress with calls from working families that want to see real reform,'' the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new president, Richard L. Trumka, above, said Monday in a telephone news conference.
docs.abstract: AFL-CIO president Richard Trumka designates Nov 5 as nationwide 'Day of Action'; calls on union members to press representatives in Congress to support health care legislation, including government-run insurance option; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't get too excited just yet. There is still a long way to go. In the Great Health Care Debate of 2009, brief flashes of news -- like Monday's announcement by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, that he will include a government-run insurance plan in the Senate bill -- are typically preceded and followed by long stretches of waiting. And this week will be no exception.
docs.abstract: Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid will include government-run insurance plan in Senate bill; has submitted several components to Congressional Budget Office for cost analysis; House Democratic leaders are set to discuss cost estimates of their version of health reform (M)
docs.snippet: Don't get too excited just yet. There is still a long way to go.      In the Great Health Care Debate of 2009, brief flashes of news -- like Monday's announcement by the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, that he will include a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't get overexcited just yet. There's still a long way to go.

headline.main: For Reid and Pelosi, Still a Long Way to Go

docs.abstract: Despite Senator Harry Reid's announcement, the final shape of the public option is far from decided -- and much depends on outstanding cost estimates.
docs.snippet: Despite Senator Harry Reid's announcement, the final shape of the public option is far from decided -- and much depends on outstanding cost estimates.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a good way. He slaps Fred Hiatt of the Washington Post hard, and he's right to do so: Hiatt attacks the Senate Finance health bill for failing to include cost-control measures that, um, are very much in the legislation.
docs.abstract: Fred Hiatt won't accept any version of fiscal responsibility that doesn't involve gutting Social Security and Medicare.
docs.snippet: Fred Hiatt won't accept any version of fiscal responsibility that doesn't involve gutting Social Security and Medicare.

docs.lead_paragraph: Harry Reid's announcement on Monday that the Senate's health care legislation is likely to contain a government-run public insurance plan - but one that would give each state the option of opting out - immediately raises the question of which states might be most likely to reject a public insurance plan.

headline.main: Would Red States Be More Likely to Opt Out?

docs.abstract: Do red state/blue state politics offer any guidance as to which states might be more likely to opt out of a public health insurance option?
docs.snippet: Do red state/blue state politics offer any guidance as to which states might be more likely to opt out of a public health insurance option?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Senate health care legislation will include a government-run insurance plan, but states would be allowed to "opt out" of it, the majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, announced Monday afternoon.
docs.abstract: After two weeks of deliberation, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, will announce a compromise public plan to be included in the Senate's health care legislation.
docs.snippet: After two weeks of deliberation, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, will announce a compromise public plan to be included in the Senate's health care legislation.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 10:59 a.m., Tuesday On Monday, after the Senate majority leader Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada, announced that he would seek a public option in the full Senate health care bill that would give states the right to opt out, Bill Samuel, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s director of government affairs, issued a statement, saying in part:

headline.main: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Members to Press Congress on Health Legislation and 'Public Option'

docs.abstract: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. sets Nov. 5 as "Day of Action" for union members to press their members of Congress to back sweeping health care legislation, including a public insurance option.
